extraction_metadata.article_title: Business Models for Emerging Technologies: The Case of Affective Computing

extracted_data.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Emotion Recognition (ER) Business Model - A disruptive business model for emerging affective computing technologies that focuses on emotion recognition solutions delivered through various channels including SaaS, technology licensing, and APIs.
synonyms_found: disruptive business model for emerging technologies
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'This paper explores the key features of disruptive business models in the affective computing industry' | Page 2: 'ER is regarded as a disruptive technology for which the academic literature has not yet investigated the design and specifics of ER-based business models'

extracted_value: ER-based business model

extracted_data.question_text: Which Business Model Canvas elements are detailed in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Value Proposition: Building emotional connection with clients, data-driven marketing decisions, customization, safety, health awareness
Customer Segment: B2B (healthcare, automotive, retail), B2C (entertainment), B2G (government)
Channels: Website, social networks, blogs, conferences, sales team, press, webinars, podcasts
Customer Relationship: Free demo, free trial period, customization, community, customer support
Revenue Streams: Software-as-a-Service, technology licensing, Emotion-as-a-Service API, product sales
Key Resources: Datasets, proprietary technology, human resources, intellectual property, equipment
Key Activities: R&D, software development, marketing & sales, customer support, hardware manufacturing
Key Partnerships: Investors, universities & research institutes, data providers, community, leading IT companies
Cost Structure: R&D, human resources, software development, IT infrastructure, sales & marketing
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 5: Complete Business Model Canvas figure showing all nine blocks with detailed elements for each

extracted_data.question_text: Which actors participate in the ecosystem of the software business model presented in the article and how do they interact?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Investors | Financial support and value addition | With offering company: Provide funding and strategic guidance | With other actors: Connect with large datasets and industry networks | Universities & Research Institutes | Research collaboration | With offering company: Conduct frontier research | With other actors: Share academic knowledge | Data Providers | Supply emotion datasets | With offering company: Provide training data | With other actors: Not specified | Community | Co-creation and feedback | With offering company: Participate in development | With other actors: Share experiences and use cases | Leading IT Companies | Technology partnerships | With offering company: Provide platforms and infrastructure | With other actors: Not specified
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4: 'Key partnerships need to be established to specialized investors that increase the value of a company beyond financial investments e.g. with large dataset' | Page 4: 'Academic partners, such as universities and research institutes, are important partners for ER providers, as they carry out research on the frontier' | Page 3: 'Community unites both end users and developers and companies, as group dynamics allow for co-creation'

extracted_data.question_text: What motivations lead to the adoption of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_value: Greater personalisation and empathy with users
Ability to deliver enhanced user experience
Popularity of virtual personal assistants and conversational AI systems
Potential for customer experience scenarios in education, gaming, healthcare
Competitive advantage through innovative technology
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'The emerging potential of the affective computing industry, as an emotional enhancement for current IT systems, is derived from its ability to deliver greater personalisation and empathy with the user' | Page 1: 'The current wave of emotion AI systems is being driven by the popularity of virtual personal assistants (VPAs) and other conversational AI-based systems'

extracted_data.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Emotion datasets → Competitive differentiation and algorithm training
Talent (data scientists and engineers) → Technology development and innovation
Free demos and trials → Customer education and adoption
R&D investment → Technology advancement and market leadership
Community building → Co-creation and dataset collection
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4: 'emotion datasets, on which the machine learning algorithms are trained... the set of labeled data and its appropriateness for the target market is what sets a company apart from the competition' | Page 4: 'talent, including data scientists and engineers, is indeed the most important resource for ER providers' | Page 3: 'free demo and free trial periods for users'

extracted_data.question_text: What prerequisites or conditions are necessary for the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Large labeled emotion datasets → Algorithm training and accuracy
Specialized talent (data scientists, engineers) → Technology development
Financial resources → R&D and operations
Customer education → Technology adoption and understanding
Regulatory compliance → Ethical data collection and processing
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4: 'emotion datasets, on which the machine learning algorithms are trained' | Page 4: 'talent, including data scientists and engineers, is indeed the most important resource' | Page 4: 'ER startups often struggle with challenges of financial resources and data access' | Page 6: 'Businesses need to comply with local regulations thoroughly before beginning research and development with human participants'

extracted_data.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Technology not fully understood by customers → Value proposition communication challenges
Proprietary technology becoming commodity → Competitive differentiation difficulties
Ethical data collection requirements → Business model implementation constraints
High R&D costs → Financial sustainability challenges
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'Since the technology is not fully understood by the customers' | Page 4: 'the easy availability of ER APIs rather makes the algorithm a commodity' | Page 6: 'Ethical issues connected with affective computing are also worth discussing, as they are threatening the overall ability of the technology to provide value' | Page 4: 'R&D, which is often long and expensive for AI solutions'

extracted_data.question_text: What challenges are identified in implementing the software business model as presented in the article?
extracted_value: Financial chasm or 'death valley' risk
Risk of failing to put together a complete new value network on time
Risk of rapid technological or business-model obsolescence
Customer lack of understanding of business value of technology
Ethical issues with data collection and privacy
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'early pioneers in affective computing face three major risks: the risk of having to endure a financial chasm or 'death valley', the risk of failing to put together a complete new value network on time, and the risk of rapid technological or business-model obsolescence' | Page 6: 'Ethical issues connected with affective computing are also worth discussing, as they are threatening the overall ability of the technology to provide value'

extracted_data.question_text: What practices are used to mitigate challenges of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Free demos and trials → Customer education and technology understanding → Increased adoption
Community building → Dataset collection and co-creation → Technology development acceleration
Partnerships with investors and academia → Financial resources and research access → Reduced development risks
Customization and customer support → Customer relationship building → Higher retention and satisfaction
Regulatory compliance → Ethical data handling → Legal and reputational risk mitigation
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3: 'showcasing their products for free. These strategies include free demo and free trial periods' | Page 3: 'Community unites both end users and developers and companies, as group dynamics allow for co-creation' | Page 4: 'Key partnerships need to be established to specialized investors' | Page 6: 'Businesses need to comply with local regulations thoroughly'

extracted_data.question_text: What metrics and quantitative results are reported in the article about the software business model?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Market size: USD 16.17 billion in 2017; Expected value: USD 88.69 billion by 2023; CAGR: 32.81%; Sample size: 80 companies analyzed; Case studies: 6 companies interviewed
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'The global affective computing market was valued at USD 16.17 billion in 2017, and is expected to reach a value of USD 88.69 billion by 2023 at a CAGR of 32.81%' | Page 2: 'We designed the business model canvas for emotion recognition (ER) solutions based on analysis of 80 companies from secondary sources, as well as six case studies'

extracted_data.question_text: Are there variations or subtypes of the software business model described in the article?
extracted_value: Emotion-as-a-Service API → Payment for number of images/videos processed
Technology licensing variations → Final product vs intermediary technology (APIs and SDKs)
Product sales → One-time sale of software and hardware
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4: 'Within technology licensing ER sector differentiates between provision of the final product, as well as intermediary technology, such as APIs and SDKs' | Page 4: 'Emotion-as-a-Service API business model, which refers to payment for a number of images/videos processed' | Page 4: 'Product sale refers to one-time sale of both software and hardware'

extracted_data.question_text: What future trends or evolutions are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Focus on customer experience scenarios in educational software, video games, diagnostic software, athletic and health performance, and autonomous cars
Unexpected novel business solutions stemming from R&D discoveries
Significant changes in business model configuration as technology evolves
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'As a second wave, AI technology is predicted to focus on customer experience scenarios, including educational software, video games, diagnostic software, athletic and health performance, and the autonomous car' | Page 6: 'Within the next years we might see unexpected novel business solutions, stemming from R&D discoveries' | Page 6: 'the future configuration of business models in use can change significantly as the technology evolves'
